captions.text:
I've had several people come up to me and
say, “What can I do to be you?”  And

the only aspect of me that’s really doable
is I can tell you what my academic pedigree

is and what I did as a kid and what things
interested me, but what I do day-to-day is

not the fulfillment of some preexisting job
description.  It’s just things that I took

interest in on my own that the general public
happened to also appreciate or like or want

access to.  And so within my job description
as Director of the Hayden Planetarium and

as an educator, as an astrophysicist, I kept
accreting other things that I did that people

responded to, positively responded to.  So,
I can tell you about the academic pedigree.

The rest, you have to create what it is that
you do best that layers onto the formal training

that may be behind it.
I think the greatest of people that have ever

been in society, they were never versions
of someone else.  They were themselves.

You don’t think about Michael Jordan the
basketball player and say, “Oh, he was just

like this other player.”  No, you don’t
even say, “He was like this player plus

that player divided by two plus this.” 
No.  He’s Michael Jordan.  I think the

greatest of people in society carved niches
that represented the unique expression of

their combinations of talents, and if everyone
had the luxury of expressing the unique combinations

of talents in this world, our society would
be transformed overnight.  It’s the great

tragedy -- people employed in ways that don’t
fully tap everything they do best in life.
I am privileged and I don’t take a day for

granted on the job about the fact that what
I do, what people most warmly receive about

what I do, are some of the things that I do
best in life.  I'm honored and flattered

by that combination of facts as they apply
to me.  So, your task is to find the combination

of facts that apply to you.  Then people
will beat a path to your door.

comments.author: Nick Baar

comments.text:
Variety is the spice of life as many would say and being yourself is the 
only way that I can see that happening. I truly do embrace my A.D.H.D, 
asthma and many other things. I embrace the ability to tap into other 
people's feelings and see how they are doing and to just live life the way 
I want to. To do the things that I love and if other people are interested 
then they can tag along too. I may only be 16 but I have gone through 
depression and since then I have embraced the memories in my days of 
depression. That alone has made me appreciate so many things that I have 
taken for granted and it just opened my eyes as to what I want to do as a 
person. I want to bring the world a little bit closer, explore our 
beautiful planet, and to see people from all corners of the Earth. I have 
found love for all people, even if they may not like me as much I still see 
them as a person, an individual, some one special. They have a purpose in 
life and I have mine, but together we have one goal, that we don't see so 
clearly... to help the world in our own special way.﻿

I try to go by this as much as possible. A quote I once heard was "only 
follow the crowd if it's going in your direction". I do stand out quite a 
lot at college, and pretty much everywhere else. There's nothing more 
indignifying than being swallowed up into insignificance.

You should just take pride in being different, there's no good or bad way 
to live your life, our existence is subjective. Just don't fret about 
trivial issues and embrace the things in life that give you pleasure, 
whatever that may be.﻿

comments.text:
But do we really have a society where 'being oneself" is even possible? I 
think not.  The most important people in history for science, liberalizing 
revolutions and technology were either greatly different from their fellow 
men, or in great opposition to the norms of society.  
Tesla and Einstein were both against using technology and science for war, 
and Einstein had bad results at elementary and high school. 

Further back in time ,the great scientists and philosophers were usually 
poor until death, or /and had problems fighting the elites of society, as 
more knowledge to the society means less power for classical hierarchies. 

What about today? Well let us be honest: In the western world as well as in 
many other countries, the youngsters like Tesla, Einstein, Newton, da 
Vinci, Sokrates, were...would all be medicated into conformity being seen 
as having "adhd" or "adaptability problems"... They would either have 
commited suicide, or would have become salesmen or ordinary workers. 

So until the culture values variation of personalities enough ,and until 
the monetary systems are gone as the requirement for survival or success, 
until the classical militaristic and religious elites are gone from 
ledership...there will not be a better world for "who you really are". 

USA and parts of Europe are among the worst areas of the world regarding 
teasing in schools, that can have devastating effects. This reveals a very 
primitive culture. In other words, only a lucky small minority will be 
succesful.  However in a more civilized society, the majority would be 
succesful in peaceful ways of 'being who they are". 
To know why and how, we have to start studying the Zeitgeist movement's 
ideas and the Venus project. 
There is no other way﻿

Have I ever been the type to care what others thought of Me?

Well maybe; only to some Degree...

But never to the point where I would Stop being ME!

It doesn't really matter how another may See...

How different, odd or weird I may appear to Be!

That's simply a vision who can't See as I See!

An Eyesight, unlike My Sight, which is far from Insight, to Me.

As long as I be who I be, think how I think and see it like I see...

There is NO ONE, who can block my sight of a much Greater Me!

You can Achieve, what you Conceive, if only you would Believe...

That YOU, and ONLY YOU, has full control of Your Own Destiny; just like Me!

Zamir﻿

comments.author: Tom Guy

comments.text:
If you're terrible at something then work at yourself. A lot what I wanted 
to say is already covered by tubetib. All I'm gonna say is have goal but 
don't worry about reaching them. The process is will yield it's own 
results. (Knowledge, acceptance, maybe even happiness).  Also, ignore 
assholes that tell you to "Be the best at sucking". Fuck them. Yeah, I 
agree with the idea that you have to learn how to make things work for you. 
But you have to be good -- or get good -- in order to do that. This whole 
feel good without actually doing good is bullshit, in my opinion. Keep 
working on yourself and you may find what you're looking for. If not, fear 
not, you will have still earned something by trying(while we're on the 
subject, fuck yoda with his "Do or do not" philosophy).

comments.text:
+tubetib
 Overall, pretty good advice.  However, "science" is not always your 
friend.  It has its fair share of con-artists (and falsehoods) waiting to 
scam you out of your money, through seemingly legitimate means.  Just 
because someone says it's "science" and good, doesn't make it so.  Use 
commonsense and always question things.
comments.author: saintgauden

comments.text: I forgot to say: avoid the mass media. This is no good for mental health.
comments.author: tubetib

comments.text:
It happens sometimes. If you go through something difficult in your life 
then that may affect you a lot. Ensure you are having the best environment. 
Are the people around you helping being your best? If no, change your 
surrounding. Have a good life: exercise, sleep well, eat well and have a 
diversity of intellectual activities. Experiment, try to do things 
differently. Always try to have the best attitude and always change the way 
you think. It is not what you think that matters but the way you think that 
matters. If all this is still now working then you may have to see a 
doctor. Maybe don't have a enough of a particular vitamin, maybe your are 
not breathing well when you sleep. Maybe you are depress and you don't even 
know. A very stupid thing may be stopping you to enjoy life. Last thing to 
say is science is your friend. Search what is the best way to do what you 
do. Track your progress, have goals, learn to be your own trainer and 
embrace science all the way to be best you can be. Hope it helps.
comments.author: tubetib

comments.author: Nath House

comments.text:
2 minutes and 38 seconds of PURE WISDOM.  He's got it.  He understands it, 
exactly.

There will always be people whom you don't please.  People who will resent 
you, who will tell you that you're being selfish for pursuing this interest 
or the other.  They will come up with plausible reasons, why you're wasting 
energy on this project or this job or this hobby.  They will tell you, you 
should be more like this guy or that woman.

But it isn't that person alone, who decides whether you are of any value to 
humankind.  It's society in general.

Do what you do best.  Follow your passions, if it's possible.  Share what 
you can, and let the rest of the world decide whether they can make use of 
the fruits of your labors.  If they can't, then perhaps some of them will 
be inspired by your efforts, or by your resultant happiness; but at least 
you will have lived a good life.

And even if nobody ever acknowledges that you did something great, you 
really never know if you have affected someone in some positive way, simply 
by the way that you lived.﻿
comments.author: DCWhatthe

comments.text: "Be yourself" ~ Neil DeGrasse Tyson (greatest astrophysicist alive!)﻿
comments.author: Epi demik

comments.text:
It is easier said than done. I know theoretically that we should be 
ourselves at all time and not care what other people think, because they 
don't have any impact whatsoever. But with the current society where 
everything you do is being watched, every action you take is being judged, 
it makes it so much more difficult. It's peer pressure﻿
comments.author: Magda Narima

comments.text:
Hell Magda! I was just reading the comments when i happened to cross by 
your comment and i'd like to give you a different perspective on it. 
Anything is easier said then done right? I'd like to believe that too, but 
that exact thinking right there can either break or make you. If everyone 
were to, in some way, take their first steps to expanding their own 
knowledge you'd be amazed by the possible effects it could have on the 
world. Bettering yourself, educating yourself(on literally anything you'd 
like to know), being more empathetic towards each-other. You say that 
theoretically we shouldn't care about what others think because they don't 
have any impact whatsoever, but that's just not the truth. Everyone around 
us is an individual who has his or her own genetic make up that makes up 
everything inside them including the human consciousness. We are coexisting 
on a planet with so much to offer us its unfathomable! Sure people will 
judge you but that's because they are unhappy with their life or they're 
dealing with a lot on their plate and feel like they're in this battle 
alone. None us are though. Easier said then done is what i used to believe. 
Granted, i'm still at such a young age but do believe when i say that 
you'll never really know of the unknown until you to venture into it. There 
are millions of great people out there who might not have the information 
that you do but that doesn't have to be the case. Set an example for them 
and lead the pack. The message is out and it's up to us to spread it and 
make it a trend in our society. Remember that we are the universe! The 
universe itself is limitless: so why should we be mindful of our limits and 
not consider our capabilities? I think that empathy should be spread across 
the world and people of all nations should invoke that inner explorer and 
maybe this world could propel us into the next century of technological and 
societal growth. Thanks if you read, i further wish you the best of luck on 
this journey my friend.
comments.author: Josiah Desouza

comments.text:
It's always easier said than done. Anyone at any moment at any time can 
come up with a reason not to do something. Let me rephrase the challenges 
you raised, which don't get me wrong are valid to some degree, basically 
are to not shy away from attention and the need to be selfish. So, are we 
taught by our parents/teachers to expect and receive attention? No not 
really (speaking for majority). If anything, they have advised us to not 
stick out and in their defense it was simply to make sure we didn't get 
into trouble. Next, are we to be selfish? Not necessarily unless you were 
raised from individuals with those traits or acquired them through peers. 
The only viable solution here, in my opinion, is to disregard the way you 
were raised and disregard the idealized norm in order to develop yourself 
as your own individual. This might mean you not being popular on facebook. 
A quote I just made up to suit this entry, "You can't catch a thief before 
a theft unless you know how to think like one."
comments.author: Naim Dut

submit to masters and not to question them.
